description: scoff +â€Ž law. Coined simultaneously by Mr Henry Irving Dale and Miss Kate L. Butler for a contest held in Boston in 1923 in which a word for "a lawless drinker of illegally made or illegally obtained liquor" was sought during the Prohibition era.

entries.meaning: (US) One who habitually violates minor laws or fails to answer trivial court summonses (such as parking tickets).
examples: The scofflaw entered the scoflsloon. He leaned an elbow on the scoffbar and rested a foot on the scoffrail. 'Waddle'y' have?" said the scoffbartender. "A little tea," said the scofflaw. So the scoffffbartender [sic] poured him something from a scoffflask [sic] under the bar. It looked like tea. The scofflaw raised it; he scofflipped it suddently. [sic] "How was it?" scoffed the scoffclerk to the scofflaw. "Scoffal," said the scofflaw, scouching.
